captions.text: Hey it's me Destin, welcome back to Smarter Every Day.
So today we're in the rocket van and I've got two little science helpers here right?
Kids: Yes, right.
Are you wearing your seatbelts?
Yes.
OK we're gonna do something pretty interesting. Check this out.
I've got a pendulum suspended from the top of our family van
and we're just gonna drive forward, we're gonna accelerate,
so if we're going that way, which direction do you think this pendulum should go? What do you think?
Kids: Yes.
Which way is it going?
Kids: My way.
That's right. It's because I'm accelerating right?
Does that make sense to you guys?
Yes sir.
OK very good, I was hoping it would make sense.
So we're gonna change it up just a little bit.
OK so now what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna replace this pendulum with a balloon.
We should see the same thing right? Let me cut this off.
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna accelerate that way
so we have the mass of the balloon and the acceleration that should net in a force and will have to react with this string right?
You guys ready?
Yes sir.
Wait a second. What just happened?
What happens when I stop?
The balloon goes backwards when I stop.
What's happening?
There it is. It's coming right at me.
Why's it doing that?
Do you wanna know?
Yeah.
Alright, I brought something to show you.
You remember I told you I was gonna bring this jar earlier? Remember that?
So it's like this. Imagine this entire van is just like this jar,
and all the air inside this van is just like the water in the jar. Does that make sense?
So let's imagine that the balloon is this bubble on top,
because the helium in the balloon is lighter than air right?
So that causes it to do what?
Kids: Go up.
Go up, that's right.
So if I've got this air that's just like it, what happens if I move the jar that way?
All that water sloshes to the back.
And when that water sloshes back this way, which direction does the bubble go?
You see that? So the air bubble moves in the direction of acceleration,
does that make sense?
I know you're five but I think you can get this.
OK so I've got my seatbelt on. If I drive forward real fast right now which direction is the balloon gonna go?
Forward.
Why will it go forward?
Because all the air's sloshing back.
That's right! Very good! Watch this.
Look at that. You see that?
So you know what that means don't you?
That means you have more air to breathe than daddy does when I'm going fast.
Did you realise that?
Kids: Nooo!
Yeah that means when I go fast, that means more air sloshes back there to you and you have more oxygen to breathe.
Doesn't it feel good back there?
OK so now we have the plumb bob right next to the balloon, so if I go forward they should spread apart right?
Let's check it out.
Is it working?
Kids: Yeah.
So what I want to do is I want to tell everybody on Smarter Every Day that if they go download
a free audio book that it'll help Smarter Every Day by sponsoring us.
Audible will, if they go to audible.com/smarter.
And so they get a free audio book, but I'm gonna do it in a funny way.
Now lean in towards me and look straight at the camera.
I know you don't know what I'm gonna do but don't laugh
because I want people to realize that they can send you to school if they get a audio book.
Does that make sense?
Yeah.
So whatever happens don't laugh. OK?
Look straight at the camera. Ready?
You don't know what I'm doing, do you?
OK you ready?
(High pitched helium voice) Thank you for supporting Smarter Every Day and if you would please download an audio book at audible.com/smarter.
Did you know daddy could talk like this?
No.
You didn't know that happened, did you?
So if you go get a free audio book it'll support Smarter Every Day and it'll help me send these kids to school.
Does that sound like a good idea?
Yes.
You should never do that, by the way. That's only for adults.
How'd you do that?
It's magical. Anyway I'm Destin, you're getting Smarter Every Day.
Please subscribe to Smarter Every Day and support our sponsor audible,
I'll leave a link somewhere and you can check it out.
Thanks, bye.
How'd you change your voice?
OK now we have the sunroof, the side window and the back open.
I'm gonna go forward, where do you think it's gonna go?
Daughter: Forward.
Son: Backwards.
Dad: So this is air, not helium?
Yes sir.
OK I think it's gonna act like the pendulum.
(laughs) Backwards.
Oh it does. We're gonna use that one.

title: A Baffling Balloon Behavior - Smarter Every Day 113

comments.text:
I've been watching this video and your explanation makes sense. Something 
else to think of would be the squat and dive of the suspension. As the car 
accelerates the rear suspension compresses, squat in racing terms, and 
during braking (decelleration) the front suspension compresses, dive. These 
are both due to the acceleration forces on the car acting about its Cg and 
more complicated physics things. 
But, the result is that when your minivan is accelerating or decellerating, 
the floor is no longer perpindicular to the ground (assuming that it was 
designed to be perpindicular from the factory). 
I don't think the cars suspension is the driving force behind the ballon, 
but it could be something else that is affecting the balloons motion.﻿
comments.author: achinaghost52

comments.text:
Awesome ... But that last action was weird... why does it go backwards? 
Ah... because it is drifting with the air backwards... and the helium

comments.text:
Nice video, thanks. It's counter intuitive, you got me there. There's 
definitely something to understand with the water bottle, but the helium 
balloon doesn't go in the front because air moves in the car, there's no 
more air to breath in the back of the car and there wouldn't be a 
significant difference in air pressure from front to back. As a matter of 
fact, it doesn't work with an air balloon suspended. Do you like "buoyancy 
is opposite to the falling direction"?﻿

comments.author: Amer Turkistani

comments.text:
+Amer Turkistani He didn't tell them to never do that. He just told them 
that it's an adults only thing, meaning they can when they are older. The 
thing about breathing helium is that it's not oxygen and your lungs need 
oxygen. The longer you breath helium the longer you are depriving your 
lungs of oxygen. Generally you're not going to just suffocate from 
breathing helium from a balloon because you will get lighthearted and/or 
pass out before it gets deadly, thus allowing you oxygen, but it's still 
not a good idea to breath it too much.

comments.author: GodFear17

comments.text:
His explanation in terms of fluid mechanics is good.  However, it's even 
more interesting, and more illustrative of a general principle, if you use 
the equivalence principle from general relativity.  When you accelerate 
forwards, it's as though (or equivalent to) switching on gravity pointing 
towards the back of the van (you're pressed backwards in your seat as the 
car accelerates).  This new gravitational field needs to be added as a 
vector to the existing gravitational field of the Earth to give an overall 
effective gravitational field that is pointed diagonally downwards and 
towards the back of the van.  In the end, when both the pendulum and the 
helium balloon are there, their strings are parallel, both pointed in the 
direction of this new effective gravitational field, one "up" (the balloon) 
and one "down" (the pendulum).  My high school students are doing an 
introduction to general relativity, and I use this video to illustrate the 
equivalence principle.  Great video, and very thought-provoking.﻿

comments.text:
Posting this here because Armathyx said he would delete my post if I 
responded under his original post. 

1. "Ugh this stupid argument again. Of course from the perspective of 
Hitler and of his millions of followers, what he did was right. Isn't it 
obvious? And from our perspective it isn't. You pick the side  you want, or 
you stay neutral like Switzerland or whatever, you have your choice."

1. It is only your "opinion" that the argument is stupid.

And you showed my point exactly... Might is always right. Hitler had a lot 
of followers and he did a lot of damage. If he would have had more 
followers who knows what would have happened. 

   "With your "belief" it shouldn't matter anyways though. Picking sides 
would be irrelevant. 

   Sure if you "believe" there is no 
meaning to life, you could decide to choose a (meaningless) side, it might 
keep your (meaningless) life preserved a little longer, or end it quicker, 
but it still doesn't change that it is all meaningless (if life is 
meaningless).

2. "Yeah well if you consider life is meaningless then too bad for you. I'm 
happy enough inventing my own meaning. Can't see how that's a bad thing. In 
the end, choosing to join a religion is still inventing your own meaning, 
since you're choosing to join it. You can join Christianity, you can join 
Islam, you can join Buddhism, or anything else if you want a predefined 
meaning for yourself. I'm a free thinker and I like to follow my own path 
so I choose to focus on my life goals and such to create my own meaning. 
Freedom is a great thing, isn't it? Or maybe you're against freedom of 
choice?..."

2. You should know now from talking with me that I do not "believe" in 
"evolution" and that I do not "believe" life is meaningless.

You are the one who said quote "I'm here by chance, as we all are. There is 
no meaning to life, but it's our job to invent our own meaning.".

 You can invent up as many different meanings as you want, but within your 
"belief" it all boils down to be meaningless anyways. 

   However "Might" is always "right" because again if someone else with a 
different "belief" is stronger than you, you are out of the picture, (maybe 
even literally in some cases). Still even this in the long run it doesn't 
really matter according to what you "believe".

  Being taken "out of the picture" is also meaningless. Death itself would 
be meaningless according to "your" "belief".

  To that, death by "suicide" would I think become a very real thing to be 
chosen by some of those who "believe" in your "belief". If it is all 
meaningless, anyways.

   If their "invented" self taught lie to cover up the meaninglessness of 
life starts to become meaningless to them, what is to stop them from just 
opting out of coming up with a new one? 

  Better yet, when an older person is getting to be a little "hard to deal 
with (according to some". According to your belief system those who 
"believe" life is meaningless can just invent up the "belief" that older 
people should be killed, because life is after all meaningless anyways. Why 
should they have to work to take care of this older person if they can just 
invent up a reason not to? I suppose though this would have to become 
majority rule first though huh (might is right)?

  Also no sense in feeling bad for those people (who may not even "believe" 
in this "belief" of life being meaningless) who are killed by someone else 
(whom they did not know believed differently than the way they did) who 
does "believe" life is meaningless and has lied to himself by inventing his 
own " self taught meaningless meaning" of killing everyone else.

   You seem to say that "believing" a religion is inventing ones own 
meaning, but that is only true if your "belief" is correct and there is no 
meaning to life. 

   You are trying to lock everyone into your "belief" that there is no 
meaning to life.
  
    If one of the other religion's (beliefs) is true then your religion is 
actually the one that is wrong, and you will be effected by whatever that 
religion was about. 

3. "I'm a free thinker and I like to follow my own path so I choose to 
focus on my life goals and such to create my own meaning. Freedom is a 
great thing, isn't it? Or maybe you're against freedom of choice?..."

3. You can "believe" anything you like. You can even "believe" that your 
"belief" is true even though it may not be.

  Again it is fine according to your "belief" that you can make life goals 
and create your own meaning.

 I am simply pointing out that according to your "belief" you are simply 
lying to yourself in doing this. 

 You are saying that there is meaning to something, that is according to 
you already proved to be meaningless. 

 It is like one calling an apple an orange to make them self feel better.

 If you want to "believe" this inside your "belief" that is fine. Just 
realize then that your own "belief" states that others are free to do the 
same thing. Also please realize that your "belief" is again just a "belief" 
it may be wrong.

 Also another point to make is that freedom in your "belief" is also 
meaningless and is only another invented meaningless meaning that you have 
deceived yourself to live by.

   It would be an invented "belief" that someone else might not even share 
with you  in their own invented up version of trying to give meaning to 
something that is meaningless.

 Their made up meaning to life may be communism, and if they are stronger 
than you, then your freedom will only be "believed" by you to exist as long 
as you are allowed to live and keep imagining it in your mind.

   It again comes back to might is right. Although it also comes back down 
to it doesn't matter (according to your "belief" that is (unless we are 
talking about your made up "belief" within your "belief", but even then it 
is still under all the makeup, meaningless)) because it is all meaningless 
according to your starting "belief".

 If you want to know, in my "belief" I am not against the freedom of 
choice. I do "believe" that there will be consequences for those choices 
though.

  I am not going to post your entire next statement because I "believe" it 
rude to use profanity and don't "believe" it is necessary. That is again is 
my "belief". The profanity will be replaced with a (*).

4. "This is the kind of argument that leads me to think you're a..." * 
..."moron."
   
It is your "opinion" that I am a moron. 

5. "Thanks for reminding me yet again that your head is hollow by claiming 
there's no evidence for evolution. A reptile giving birth to a bird xD 
You're remarkably stupid."

 Again "your" "opinion". 

   My point in asking for an experienced living example of a reptile giving 
birth to a bird (or at least laying an egg that hatches into a bird) was 
because you will not admit that what you "believe" (Macro-evolution not 
Micro evolution) is just that, a "belief".

  Along with this you will also not show how it can be personally 
experienced today to be called science. 

Science is knowledge, knowledge is a clear and certain perspective of that 
which exists.

  In order to be able to observe that which exists it must actually exist. 
Evolution is just a "belief". 

 To explain further why I mention the reptile giving birth to a bird, it is 
because loosely stated that is what your "belief" is, only that your 
"belief" adds that it takes millions of years to happen and that the 
"change" happens through millions of generations of reptiles "evolving". 
Which means it cannot today be called science.
 
  Truth be told I have stated this before, but science was born with the 
first man, and it will die with the last man.

 Even if one earthly man claimed to have lived 20+ billion years, and 
claimed to have observed personally evolution happening somehow from the 
beginning, (which no man has ever stepped forward claiming they have 
lived to see evolution from the start, and which according to "your" 
"belief's" common "disbelief" of God it would be an unlikely possibility 
because they would have had to have themselves existed before existence) 
them claiming to see it would not make it science for another person who 
had not seen it. It could only be passed on by word of mouth or writing and 
then "believed" on by "faith" by another person, unless that person them 
self could then go and experience the same thing. 

   How does the person hearing the claim know for sure that the person 
declaring it isn't lying unless they can experience it for them self? If 
they did know, they would not have to believe it by "faith".

 For instance people who "believe" what the bible says about Jesus are 
believing by "faith" on what other people declared to have seen in their 
lifetime . It yes could really have happened (which I "believe" it did), 
but that does not mean it is science unless I can personally experience 
today what they experienced. 

   This is why I "personally" "believe" Jesus said "Thomas, because thou 
hast seen me, thou hast believed:blessed they that have not seen, and have 
believed." John 20:29 KJV.

  This is getting back to the point that Destin is showing science in his 
experiment because it can actually be personally experienced by other 
people.


  6. "I'll tell you a way to tell right from wrong: Make your own mind 
about it, and get people to agree with you. It's meaningful to you and to 
the people around you and that's more than enough to establish laws and get 
the world going." 

6. According to your "belief", that would only be your your "belief" of how 
to tell right from wrong. As we have already established your "belief" is 
that life is meaningless.

  In your "belief" system, someone is free to invent whatever way they 
want, so that they can tell right from wrong. 

 They don't even have to invent a way to do it if they don't want to, 
because in the end it is all meaningless anyways according to "your" 
"belief system" not mine.  This does however show again how your "belief" 
leads to "might" equals "right".

7. "You know what doesn't work though, is basing your morality on some 
imaginary being you have ZERO evidence of."

7. This is again is only your opinion based on your "belief system" (which 
leads one to "believe" quote "I'm here by chance, as we all are. There is 
no meaning to life, but it's our job to invent our own meaning.").

   
 I have expressed this several times in another argument with you that I 
admit that my "belief" that God created cannot be personally experienced to 
be called science. You however will not admit that your "belief" cannot be 
personally experienced to be called science either.

  Maybe though that is a part of your "belief" as well (although I think 
according to your "belief system's" "belief" it would have to be one of 
those invented up "beliefs" so as to give imaginary meaning to ones already 
meaningless life).

8. "Don't throw bricks when you live in a glass house."
 
8. According to your "belief" system my glass house would be meaningless, 
and so my glass bricks that I would throw would also be meaningless as well.

  I don't understand why one who "believes" in your "belief" system would 
concern themselves with the meaningless damage that meaningless glass 
bricks could cause to someone else's meaningless glass house, 
unless of course that person has again invented up some meaningless meaning 
to mask their already meaningless existence according to their own 
meaningless "belief system".

9. "Tired of argueing with a hillbilly with a potato for a brain. Don't 
bother writting a reply, I'll just delete it. Yeah it's ad hominem, so 
what, you deserve to be ridiculed, you're insane."

9. Again this is just your opinion.

As far as why you threatened me not to reply back, that is something other 
people can sort out using their own various "beliefs". 

 I will admit I don't understand how youtube works entirely so I don't know 
how you could delete my comment other than deleting your comment leaving 
mine hanging (if that is even possible). 

Still with this message I have indeed replied.

   I will also post our entire original argument (minus your profanity 
which I will replace with a "*") after a series of --,  and I will post 
this whole message under another person's comment besides your own, in case 
you do carry out your threat to delete my comments (somehow?). The reason I 
do this is because 
according to "my" "belief" this argument does matter.

  If you ever do get tired of your "belief" of a meaningless life. I would 
love to share with you my "belief" in my God, who I "believe" loved you so 
much that he sent his son to die for your sins, be buried, and then rise 
again on the third day (according to the scriptures that told that it would 
happen before it did happen). My "belief" even "believes" that there were 
real people who made declarations and writings about how they personally 
experienced these events happening so that people like me can choose to 
"believe" what they said by "faith".

""I'm here by chance, as we all are. There is no meaning to life, but it's

CAR DEC Responded:

 This is the kind of argument that leads me to think you're a..." *

I'll tell you a way to tell right from wrong: Make your own mind about it,

You know what doesn't work though, is basing your morality on some

Tired of argueing with a hillbilly with a potato for a brain. Don't bother 
writting a reply, I'll just delete it. Yeah it's ad hominem, so what, you

"1. "Ugh this stupid argument again. Of course from the perspective of 
Hitler and of his millions of followers, what he did was right. Isn't it 
obvious? And from our perspective it isn't. You pick the side  you want, or 
you stay neutral like Switzerland or whatever, you have your choice."

1. It is only your "opinion" that the argument is stupid.

And you showed my point exactly... Might is always right. Hitler had a lot

   "With your "belief" it shouldn't matter anyways though. Picking sides

meaningless).

2. "Yeah well if you consider life is meaningless then too bad for you. I'm 
happy enough inventing my own meaning. Can't see how that's a bad thing. In 
the end, choosing to join a religion is still inventing your own meaning, 
since you're choosing to join it. You can join Christianity, you can join 
Islam, you can join Buddhism, or anything else if you want a predefined 
meaning for yourself. I'm a free thinker and I like to follow my own path 
so I choose to focus on my life goals and such to create my own meaning. 
Freedom is a great thing, isn't it? Or maybe you're against freedom of 
choice?..."

2. You should know now from talking with me that I do not "believe" in 
"evolution" and that I do not "believe" life is meaningless.

You are the one who said quote "I'm here by chance, as we all are. There is 
no meaning to life, but it's our job to invent our own meaning.".

 You can invent up as many different meanings as you want, but within your 
"belief" it all boils down to be meaningless anyways. 

   However "Might" is always "right" because again if someone else with a 
different "belief" is stronger than you, you are out of the picture, (maybe 
even literally in some cases). Still even this in the long run it doesn't 
really matter according to what you "believe".

  Being taken "out of the picture" is also meaningless. Death itself would 
be meaningless according to "your" "belief".

  To that, death by "suicide" would I think become a very real thing to be 
chosen by some of those who "believe" in your "belief". If it is all 
meaningless, anyways.

   If their "invented" self taught lie to cover up the meaninglessness of 
life starts to become meaningless to them, what is to stop them from just 
opting out of coming up with a new one? 

  Better yet, when an older person is getting to be a little "hard to deal 
with (according to some". According to your belief system those who 
"believe" life is meaningless can just invent up the "belief" that older 
people should be killed, because life is after all meaningless anyways. Why 
should they have to work to take care of this older person if they can just 
invent up a reason not to? I suppose though this would have to become 
majority rule first though huh (might is right)?

  Also no sense in feeling bad for those people (who may not even "believe" 
in this "belief" of life being meaningless) who are killed by someone else 
(whom they did not know believed differently than the way they did) who 
does "believe" life is meaningless and has lied to himself by inventing his 
own " self taught meaningless meaning" of killing everyone else.

   You seem to say that "believing" a religion is inventing ones own 
meaning, but that is only true if your "belief" is correct and there is no 
meaning to life. 

   You are trying to lock everyone into your "belief" that there is no 
meaning to life.
  
    If one of the other religion's (beliefs) is true then your religion is 
actually the one that is wrong, and you will be effected by whatever that 
religion was about. 

3. "I'm a free thinker and I like to follow my own path so I choose to 
focus on my life goals and such to create my own meaning. Freedom is a 
great thing, isn't it? Or maybe you're against freedom of choice?..."

3. You can "believe" anything you like. You can even "believe" that your 
"belief" is true even though it may not be.

  Again it is fine according to your "belief" that you can make life goals 
and create your own meaning.

 I am simply pointing out that according to your "belief" you are simply 
lying to yourself in doing this. 

 You are saying that there is meaning to something, that is according to 
you already proved to be meaningless. 

 It is like one calling an apple an orange to make them self feel better.

 If you want to "believe" this inside your "belief" that is fine. Just 
realize then that your own "belief" states that others are free to do the 
same thing. Also please realize that your "belief" is again just a "belief" 
it may be wrong.

 Also another point to make is that freedom in your "belief" is also 
meaningless and is only another invented meaningless meaning that you have 
deceived yourself to live by.

   It would be an invented "belief" that someone else might not even share 
with you  in their own invented up version of trying to give meaning to 
something that is meaningless.

 Their made up meaning to life may be communism, and if they are stronger 
than you, then your freedom will only be "believed" by you to exist as long 
as you are allowed to live and keep imagining it in your mind.

   It again comes back to might is right. Although it also comes back down 
to it doesn't matter (according to your "belief" that is (unless we are 
talking about your made up "belief" within your "belief", but even then it 
is still under all the makeup, meaningless)) because it is all meaningless 
according to your starting "belief".

 If you want to know, in my "belief" I am not against the freedom of 
choice. I do "believe" that there will be consequences for those choices 
though.

  I am not going to post your entire next statement because I "believe" it 
rude to use profanity and don't "believe" it is necessary. That is again is 
my "belief". The profanity will be replaced with a (*).

4. "This is the kind of argument that leads me to think you're a..." * 
..."moron."
   
It is your "opinion" that I am a moron. 

5. "Thanks for reminding me yet again that your head is hollow by claiming 
there's no evidence for evolution. A reptile giving birth to a bird xD 
You're remarkably stupid."

 Again "your" "opinion". 

   My point in asking for an experienced living example of a reptile giving 
birth to a bird (or at least laying an egg that hatches into a bird) was 
because you will not admit that what you "believe" (Macro-evolution not 
Micro evolution) is just that, a "belief".

  Along with this you will also not show how it can be personally 
experienced today to be called science. 

Science is knowledge, knowledge is a clear and certain perspective of that 
which exists.

  In order to be able to observe that which exists it must actually exist. 
Evolution is just a "belief". 

 To explain further why I mention the reptile giving birth to a bird, it is 
because loosely stated that is what your "belief" is, only that your 
"belief" adds that it takes millions of years to happen and that the 
"change" happens through millions of generations of reptiles "evolving". 
Which means it cannot today be called science.
 
  Truth be told I have stated this before, but science was born with the 
first man, and it will die with the last man.

 Even if one earthly man claimed to have lived 20+ billion years, and 
claimed to have observed personally evolution happening somehow from the 
beginning, (which no man has ever stepped forward claiming they have 
lived to see evolution from the start, and which according to "your" 
"belief's" common "disbelief" of God it would be an unlikely possibility 
because they would have had to have themselves existed before existence) 
them claiming to see it would not make it science for another person who 
had not seen it. It could only be passed on by word of mouth or writing and 
then "believed" on by "faith" by another person, unless that person them 
self could then go and experience the same thing. 

   How does the person hearing the claim know for sure that the person 
declaring it isn't lying unless they can experience it for them self? If 
they did know, they would not have to believe it by "faith".

 For instance people who "believe" what the bible says about Jesus are 
believing by "faith" on what other people declared to have seen in their 
lifetime . It yes could really have happened (which I "believe" it did), 
but that does not mean it is science unless I can personally experience 
today what they experienced. 

   This is why I "personally" "believe" Jesus said "Thomas, because thou 
hast seen me, thou hast believed:blessed they that have not seen, and have 
believed." John 20:29 KJV.

  This is getting back to the point that Destin is showing science in his 
experiment because it can actually be personally experienced by other 
people.


  6. "I'll tell you a way to tell right from wrong: Make your own mind 
about it, and get people to agree with you. It's meaningful to you and to 
the people around you and that's more than enough to establish laws and get 
the world going." 

6. According to your "belief", that would only be your your "belief" of how 
to tell right from wrong. As we have already established your "belief" is 
that life is meaningless.

  In your "belief" system, someone is free to invent whatever way they 
want, so that they can tell right from wrong. 

 They don't even have to invent a way to do it if they don't want to, 
because in the end it is all meaningless anyways according to "your" 
"belief system" not mine.  This does however show again how your "belief" 
leads to "might" equals "right".

7. "You know what doesn't work though, is basing your morality on some 
imaginary being you have ZERO evidence of."

7. This is again is only your opinion based on your "belief system" (which 
leads one to "believe" quote "I'm here by chance, as we all are. There is 
no meaning to life, but it's our job to invent our own meaning.").

   
 I have expressed this several times in another argument with you that I 
admit that my "belief" that God created cannot be personally experienced to 
be called science. You however will not admit that your "belief" cannot be 
personally experienced to be called science either.

  Maybe though that is a part of your "belief" as well (although I think 
according to your "belief system's" "belief" it would have to be one of 
those invented up "beliefs" so as to give imaginary meaning to ones already 
meaningless life).

8. "Don't throw bricks when you live in a glass house."
 
8. According to your "belief" system my glass house would be meaningless, 
and so my glass bricks that I would throw would also be meaningless as well.

  I don't understand why one who "believes" in your "belief" system would 
concern themselves with the meaningless damage that meaningless glass 
bricks could cause to someone else's meaningless glass house, 
unless of course that person has again invented up some meaningless meaning 
to mask their already meaningless existence according to their own 
meaningless "belief system".

9. "Tired of argueing with a hillbilly with a potato for a brain. Don't 
bother writting a reply, I'll just delete it. Yeah it's ad hominem, so 
what, you deserve to be ridiculed, you're insane."

9. Again this is just your opinion.

As far as why you threatened me not to reply back, that is something other 
people can sort out using their own various "beliefs". 

 I will admit I don't understand how youtube works entirely so I don't know 
how you could delete my comment other than deleting your comment leaving 
mine hanging (if that is even possible). 

Still with this message I have indeed replied.

   I will also post our entire original argument (minus your profanity 
which I will replace with a "*") after a series of --,  and I will post 
this whole message under another person's comment besides your own, in case 
you do carry out your threat to delete my comments (somehow?). The reason I 
do this is because 
according to "my" "belief" this argument does matter.

  If you ever do get tired of your "belief" of a meaningless life. I would 
love to share with you my "belief" in my God, who I "believe" loved you so 
much that he sent his son to die for your sins, be buried, and then rise 
again on the third day (according to the scriptures that told that it would 
happen before it did happen). My "belief" even "believes" that there were 
real people who made declarations and writings about how they personally 
experienced these events happening so that people like me can choose to 
"believe" what they said by "faith"."﻿

comments.author: Jim Roberts

comments.text:
+Jim Roberts  Jim  it is really simple if you think of it this way; The 
helium in the balloon is lighter than the air in the van (that's why it 
floats). When the van starts to move the heaver stuff resist moving more 
than the lighter stuff. since the air is heaver than the helium it forces 
the balloon to the front as it (the air) is forced to the back of the van. 
Did I explain it well enough?
comments.author: WHEREISTHEREASON

comments.text: It literally explains it in the video
comments.author: TheAsianPersuasion

comments.text:
Essentially, your turning the van on its rear as you accelerate. Imaging 
the jar sitting on its side then turning back upright so the "bubbles" 
(ballon) will go to the (top of the jar) front of the car. That's the best 
explanation I can give I'm sorry if that doesn't help.
comments.author: TheAc2011

comments.text:
+Jim Roberts /shouldnt so when air sloshes to the back, it should also push 
the back/

Go back and watch the part of the video with the bubble in the jar of water.

Since helium, air and water are all fluids, "helium in air" acts just like 
"air in water".

comments.author: Jim Roberts

comments.text:
The helium balloon is lighter (aka "less dense") than air, and so the air 
displaces it when the air -- due to inertia -- sloshes backwards when he 
accelerates the van.

Just like with the air bubble in the jar full of water.

comments.text:
I think the acceleration causes the gas inside of the cabin to become 
slightly more compressed in the back of the van and slightly less 
compressed in the front, with a gradient in-between. The balloon moves 
forward because it is moving to a lower pressure zone, this effect is 
pronounced because Helium is already lighter than air and thus is effected 
more by subtle changes in it the cabin gas composition... 
Just a guess though....﻿

comments.text:
It all comes down to the fact that helium is lighter than air. So when the 
car brakes, the air molecules do follow the laws of inertia and collect in 
the back of the minivan. But this displaces the helium-filled balloon, and 
pushes it towards the front of the car, away from the collection of air 
molecules.﻿
